FacilityName: Plumrose dba JBS Prepared Foods - Council Bluffs 2

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary
RMP Report For JBS Prepared Foods - Council Bluffs 2 (JBS)
Executive Summary
§68.155
(a) Accidental Release Prevention & Emergency Response Policies
JBS is committed to protecting facility personnel, the public, and the environment from any workplace and accidental release hazards. Appropriate responses to release of Ammonia (anhydrous) are documented in the Risk Management Program (RMP) document. Safety, environmental protection, and risk management programs will be fully implemented by JBS Prepared Foods personnel and contractors and are coordinated with
community emergency responders for emergency planning and response efforts.

(b) Stationary Source and Regulated Substance Handled 
JBS provides employment for approximately 214 workers at 3210 21st Avenue, Council Bluffs, Iowa 51501.  This facility is a meat processing plant owned by JBS USA, LLC, which has headquarters at 1770 Promontory Cir., Greeley, CO 80634. After reviewing the facility operations and the RMP regulations, it was determined that the entire facility is considered one process. JBS receives raw meat (i.e., pork, turkey, and beef). The meat is processed by washing, grinding, mixing with spices, and cooking. The cooked meat is smoked, sliced, and packaged (sandwich meat) for retail sale. From the time the meat products are received and throughout the processes conducted, the facility maintains a cool temperature utilizing a refrigeration process that uses Ammonia (anhydrous). Based on the facility processes and applicable regulations, it was determined that the facility is subject to Program 3 of the RMP regulation.

(c) General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
Process Safety Information: JBS completed a compilation of written process safety information to be used in conducting the process hazard analysis (PHA). The last PHA was conducted on April 1 and 2, 2024, using the process safety information gathered in order to identify and unde

rstand the hazards posed by the Ammonia refrigeration process. This process safety information included information pertaining to the hazards of Ammonia (anhydrous), information pertaining to the technology of the Ammonia refrigeration process, and information pertaining to the equipment utilized in the Ammonia refrigeration process.

Process Hazard Analysis: JBS updates and re-validates the PHA as necessary and at least every five (5) years. The PHA was conducted using the methodology specified in 40 CFR 68.67, and was performed by a team with expertise in engineering and process operations, including at least one employee who has expertise in the Ammonia refrigeration process, and at least one member knowledgeable in the specific PHA methodology used. A system has been established to promptly address the team's findings and recommendations; assure that the recommendations are resolved in a timely manner and that the resolution is documented; document what actions are to be completed; complete actions as soon as possible; develop a written schedule of when these actions are to be completed; and communicate the actions to operating, maintenance and other employees whose work assignments are in the process and who may be affected by the recommendations or actions.

Operating Procedures: JBS developed and implemented written operating procedures to provide clear instructions for safely conducting activities at each operation where Ammonia (anhydrous) is utilized. These written operating procedures are consistent with the process safety information and address steps for each operating phase, operating limitations, safety and health considerations, and safety systems and their functions. These operating procedures are readily accessible to employees who work in or maintain the Ammonia refrigeration process. These operating procedures are reviewed as often as necessary to assure that they reflect current operating practice, including changes that result from changes in p

rocess chemicals, technology, and equipment, and changes to the facility. JBS annually certifies that these operating procedures are current and accurate. JBS has developed and implemented safe work practices to provide for the control of hazards during operations such as lockout/tagout; confined space entry; opening process equipment or piping; and control entrance into the JBS facility by maintenance, contractor, laboratory, or other support personnel. These safe work practices apply to employees and contractor employees.

Training: JBS provides training for each employee associated with the Ammonia refrigeration process. This training includes an overview of the process and operating procedures as outlined by 40 CFR 68.71. Refresher training is provided at least every three (3) years and more often if necessary. JBS documents and maintains records of the employee, the date of training, and the means used to verify that the employee understood the training.

Mechanical Integrity: JBS has the following written documents and programs to maintain the on-going integrity of the equipment used in the Ammonia refrigeration process (i.e., storage tanks, piping systems, etc); additionally, inspections, testing, equipment deficiencies, and quality assurance are addressed:

Mechanical Integrity Study of Process Equipment
Preventative Maintenance Program: Each person who has responsibilities to perform maintenance on the ammonia process components receives training at least every three (3) years and more often if necessary.

Management of Change: JBS established and implemented written procedures to manage changes to process chemicals, technology, equipment, and procedures; and, changes to JBS that affect the Ammonia refrigeration process. These procedures assure that appropriate considerations are addressed prior to any change. Employees involved in operating a process and maintenance and contract employees whose job tasks will be affected by a change in the process are info

rmed of, and trained in, the change prior to startup of the process or affected part of the process. If a change results in a change in the process safety information, such information is updated accordingly. If a change in the process results in a change in the operation procedures or practices, such procedures or practices are updated accordingly.

Pre-startup Review: JBS performs a pre-startup review according to 40 CFR 68.77 when the modification is significant enough to require a change in the process safety information.

Compliance Audits: JBS certifies that they have evaluated compliance with the provisions of 40 CFR, Part 68 at least every three years to verify that procedures developed under 40 CFR, Part 68 are adequate and are being followed. The compliance audit is conducted by at least one person knowledgeable in the Ammonia refrigeration process. A report of the findings of the audit is developed, and JBS promptly determines and documents an appropriate response to each of the findings of the compliance audit, and document that deficiencies have been corrected. Records of the two (2) most recent compliance audit reports are maintained.

Incident Investigation: JBS investigates each incident, which results in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of Ammonia (anhydrous). Incident investigations are initiated as promptly as possible, but no later than 48 hours following the incident. The incident investigation team consists of at least one person knowledgeable in the process involved, including a contract employee if the incident involved work of the contractor, and other persons with appropriate knowledge and experience to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident. A report is prepared at the conclusion of the investigation, and JBS has a system to promptly address and resolve the incident and report findings and recommendations. Resolutions and corrective actions are documented. Reports are reviewed with all affected personnel whose

job tasks are relevant to the incident findings including contract employees where applicable. Incident investigations reports are retained for five years.

Employee Participation: JBS has developed a written plan of action regarding the implementation of employee participation. The facility consults with employees on the conduct and development of process hazard analyses and on the development of the other elements of process management. JBS provides employees access to process hazard analyses and to all other information required to be developed under 40 CFR, Part 68.

Hot Work Permit: JBS issues a hot work permit for hot work operations conducted on or near the Ammonia refrigeration process.

Contractors: JBS, when selecting a contractor, obtains and evaluates information regarding the contract owner or operator's safety performance and programs. JBS informs the contract owner or operator of the known potential toxic release hazards related to the contractor's work and the Ammonia refrigeration process. JBS explains to the contract owner or operator, the applicable provisions of the Emergency Response Program. JBS has developed and implemented safe work practices consistent with 40 CFR 68.69 (d), to control the entrance, presence, and exit of the contract owner or operator and contract employees in the Ammonia refrigeration process areas. JBS periodically evaluates the performance of the contract owner or operator in fulfilling their obligations as specified below. Contract owners or operators assure that each contract employee is trained in the work practices necessary to safely perform his/her job. Contract owners or operators assure that each contract employee is instructed in the known potential toxic release hazards related to his/her job and the Ammonia refrigeration process, and the applicable provisions of the emergency action plan. Contract owners and operators document that each contract employee has received and understood the training required. Contr

act owners and operators are required to have records of the identity of the contract employee, the date of training, and the means used to verify that the employee understood the training. The contract owner or operator assures that each contract employee follows the safety rules of JBS, including the safe work practices required by 40 CFR 68.69 (d). The contract owner or operator advises JBS of any unique hazards presented by the contract owner or operator's work, or of any hazards found by the contract owner or operator's work.

(d) Five-year Accident History
During the past five (5) years JBS has not had any accidental releases from the Ammonia refrigeration process that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on-site, or known off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage. 

(e) Emergency Response Program
JBS has developed and implemented an emergency response program for the purpose of protecting public health and the environment. This program includes the following elements:
1) An emergency response plan, which is maintained on-site and contains at least the following elements:
a. Procedures for informing the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases;
b. Documentation of proper first-aid and emergency medical treatment necessary to treat accidental human exposures; and
c. Procedures and measures for emergency response after an accidental release of Ammonia (anhydrous)
2) Procedures for the use of emergency response equipment and for its inspection, testing, and maintenance;
3) Training for all employees in relevant procedures; and 
4) Procedures to review and update, as appropriate, the emergency response plan to reflect changes at JBS and to ensure that employees are informed of the changes.

(f) Planned Changes to Improve Safety
In an attempt to ensure a continual improvement in the facility worker protection and release prevention programs, training co

ncerning this safety and environmental program and others are conducted annually. This training requires the attendance of all personnel whose job is related to the Ammonia (anhydrous) refrigeration process. Additionally, audits are performed as specified in the RMP Plan, which requires JBS to assess areas of the RMP Plan that may need to be changed or improved.
